headline: Biden touts new Intel mega-plant in State of the Union address
author: Kaylyn Hlavaty
sentences: He blamed automobile sales as one of the reasons for inflation, reiterating that there weren't enough semiconductors to make all the cars to fit the demand— a problem that state officials say can be fixed with the new Intel factory coming to Licking County.

WASHINGTON — During the State of the Union address on Tuesday night, President Joe Biden touted Intel’s plan to take over 1,000 acres of empty land 20 miles east of Columbus and build a $20 billion semiconductor mega site.

He argued that the way to fight inflation is to re-imagine and redefine the Rust Belt by having more infrastructure and innovation in the states, which he said would drive down costs by boosting manufacturing.
The mega project, which could balloon to $100 billion within the next decade, is expected to employ 3,000 people, earning an average salary of $135,000 a year.

Soldier mentioned
Biden also talked about how his administration is providing job training and debt-free medical care to veterans who need care after serving.

"It won’t look like much, but if you stop and look closely, you’ll see a field of dreams, the ground on which America’s future will be built,” Biden said.
Biden used the Intel factory to mention his Bipartisan Innovation Act that will make investments in emerging technologies and American manufacturing.
“That’s where Intel, the American company that helped build Silicon Valley, is going to build its $20 billion semiconductor mega site."
